awd_titl_txt: Increasing the Visibility of Women's Research in Mathematics through Graduate Student Participation in National Workshops
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students in workshops presented by the Association for Women in Mathematics at four major U.S. mathematics meetings in 2018-2020: SIAM 2018 (July, Portland), JMM 2019 (January, Baltimore), SIAM CSE 2019 (February, Spokane), and JMM 2020 (January, Denver). These workshops will bring rising women stars and current mathematical leaders together with graduate students and recent graduates from a variety of fields in pure and applied mathematics. By creating a rich intellectual community centered on shared research interests, the events are structured to generate new mentoring relations, new research collaborations, and increased activity in the associated research areas.  Moreover, these events at highly visible national meetings benefit the entire mathematical community by showcasing the excellent mathematical work done by women.
 
Each workshop has a particular research focus.  Leaders in each research field will introduce younger mathematicians to a deeper understanding of the field and its connections with their own work.  Graduate students will, in turn, share their research during poster sessions and small group interactions.  The research topics to be highlighted in these workshops include modeling boundaries of objects in two and three dimensions, computational topology, and other topics that span a broad spectrum of current mathematical problems. The workshops aim to promote the research of young women mathematicians and to increase the visibility of research done by women mathematicians on questions of current interest. For more information on the workshops, see 
https://sites.google.com/site/awmmath/awm-at-siam and 
https://sites.google.com/site/awmmath/awm-at-jmm

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the Association for Women in Mathematics is to create a community in which women and girls can thrive in their mathematical endeavors, and to promote equitable opportunity and treatment of women and others of marginalized genders and gender identities across the mathematical sciences. The AWM workshop is designed with the goal of increasing the visibility of women in mathematics by providing an opportunity for early-career women, including graduate students, to present their work at a national conference. Networking events facilitate interactions among graduate students, postdocs, faculty and other professional mathematicians. 

Financial support provided by the NSF was used to provide travel funding and stipends for graduate student participation in workshops at national meetings in 2018, 2019, 2020 and 2021: the annual Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) and the annual Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM). The students were able to present research posters, attend the AWM special sessions, the AWM career panel, and participate in the AWM mentoring program and luncheon. 

  • The AWM workshop at SIAM 2018 was held July 9 -- 10 in Portland, OR was entitled "Shape Analysis and Modeling", the topic of the WiSh (Women in Shape Analysis) Workshop hosted by the Nesin Mathematics Village in June 2016. The career panel was entitled "Perspectives and Advice from Women in Research."

  • The AWM workshop at JMM 2019 was held January 15 -- 19, 2019 in Baltimore, MD. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "WinCompTop: Applied and Computational Topology." 

  • The AWM workshop at SIAM CSE 2019 was held February 25 -- March 1 in Spokane, WA. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "Data Science and Mathematics", a follow up to the WiSDM (Women in the Science of Data and Mathematics) Workshop held at the Institute for Computational and Experimental Research in Mathematics (ICERM) in July, 2017.

  • The AWM workshop at JMM 2020 was held January 15 -- 18 in Denver, CO. The topic of the AWM Special Session was "Women in Several Complex Variables (WinSCV)", a follow-up to the WinSCV Workshop held at American Institute of Mathematics (AIM) in April, 2019.

  • The AWM workshop at the 2020 SIAM Annual Meeting took place virtually, July 8 -- 10, and was hosted by the Women in Mathematics of Materials (WiMM) Research Network.

  • The AWM Workshop at the 2021 Joint Mathematics Meetings was also held virtually January 6 -- 9.  The AWM Workshop was hosted by Women in Analysis (WoAN). The poster session had an asynchronous format. Participants met twice with the organizers prior to the JMM, virtually,  in order to discuss best practices for poster presentations and strategies to make the best out of their JMM experience. Adapting to the virtual setting of the meetings, poster presenters prepared pre-recorded presentations to accompany their posters. Graduate student participants formed peer teams of three with the goal of providing each other with feedback while preparing the video recorded presentations. 

  • The AWM workshop at the SIAM Annual Meeting in 2021, held virually, July 19 -- 20, was organized by the AWM Research Network Women in Control (WiC). The topic of the workshop was "Control and Optimization in Differential Equations."

All of the in-person workshops had similar formats: research-focused special sessions, a panel discussion, a poster session for graduate students, and a luncheon. The research focus of each meeting drew from a topic from one of the Research Collaboration Workshops for Women, a recent AWM initiative where women graduate students, postdocs, and more advanced women spend one week actively working on projects proposed by senior women in the field. The graduate student posters came from various research areas, but several were from the research focus of the special sessions. Attendance at the research focused special sessions aided graduate students in understanding the greater context for their research while connecting women graduate students immediately to the larger network of research-active women.

Intellectual Merit : 

These events brought together the rising women stars and current mathematical leaders from a variety of fields in pure and applied mathematics. By creating a rich intellectual community centered on shared research interests, the workshop activities generated new mentoring relationships, new research collaborations, and increased activity in those research areas.

Broader Impacts : 

AWM activities work to address that lag by supporting women in their mathematical endeavors. The four workshop events supported by this grant promoted networking, mentoring relationships, and research collaborations among women, especially those just beginning their careers. Such relationships can lead to a lifetime of professional success. Moreover, the events at JMM and SIAM benefited the entire mathematical community by showcasing the excellent work done by women.
